p: Unfortunately, many African countries are dependent on donor funding to provide treatment and related services. This means that the sustainability of treatment is threatened. An analysis by Resch, Ryckman, and Hecht looking at 12 African countries found under their ‘maximum effort scenario’, across the countries “total average annual government expenditure on AIDS would increase by 2·5 times, reaching $5·1 billion, which is sufficient to cover 64% of total AIDS financial needs’ and “although upper-middle-income countries, such as Botswana, Namibia, and South Africa, would become financially self-reliant, lower-income countries, such as Mozambique and Ethiopia, would remain heavily dependent on donor funds” (Resch et al. 2015).
